title: CFMEU 'at war' against freedom of association, judge warns
text:
Justice Snaden, a former junior barrister and ex-student Liberal politician appointed to the court by Attorney-General Christian Porter shortly before the May federal election, said he was reluctant to add to previous and "unambiguously scathing" comments about the CFMEU's lawless history.

"I do not relish the prospect of adding my name to the long list of judicial officers

whose exasperated admonitions appear to have been met with studied indifference," he said.

He quoted Mr Setka at a union rally in 2017 to note that the judges' criticism had, on one occasion, been publicly dismissed "as the invalid mutterings of snobbish hypocrites who 'call us criminals [and] all sorts of things [and] fine us millions of dollars [despite having] probably never done a day’s work in their li[ves]'".

However, he found the CFMEU's history of breaches showed it was "wholly unmoved" by the prospect of digging into its members' "big pots of gold" to "fight the good fight" and that this called for higher penalties to deter others.

Mr Pattinson was "merely the latest foot soldier in what seems to be the union’s war against free association on Australian building sites", he said.

"One might be forgiven for doubting that there might not be others who stand ready to do similar things in the future."

Justice Snaden said the CFMEU's "no ticket, no start" policy had been the subject of judicial criticism on many occasions and had cost the union and its members "substantial sums of money" in penalties.

"That it continues to be effected by the likes of Mr Pattinson can only be because those more senior in the union’s hierarchy have endorsed it (whether expressly or by their abject failure to eliminate it)."

Advertisement

The judge also refused to grant the CFMEU a discount for admitting to the breaches at an early stage, after finding that to do so would only "reward that adventure in self-interest".

"To put it in simpler terms: the union regards the imposition of penalties as an acceptable cost of the manner in which it chooses to operate.

"I do not accept that its admissions in this case – as opposed to the penalties imposed in the many that preceded it – should be understood to reflect some sudden realisation that perhaps it ought to act lawfully and ought not to insist upon the forced co-option of construction workers to its ranks."

Justice Snaden imposed maximum fines on the CFMEU and ordered that Mr Pattinson not accept money from the union to pay his individual fine.
description: A Federal Court judge has blasted John Setka's union for preventing non-members from working on building sites and relying on its 'pots of gold' to pay fines.
